host_species.notes: Primary mycorrhizal partner; more abundant in 40-60 year old second-growth stands.
Common co-host in PNW conifer forests.

species.soil_type_notes: Moist, slightly acidic soils with thick duff layer; more soil moisture retained by rotted wood. Fruiting begins 7-10 days after significant fall rains.
fauna_partners: insect-resistant fruiting bodies (rarely infested by fly larvae)
sources: Oregon Encyclopedia: Chanterelle Mushrooms by Dale Baer — https://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/mushroomschanterelles/
species.manual_notes: Scientific name corrected to C. formosus (PNW species, distinct from European C. cibarius per Redhead et al. 1997). Elevation minimum ~1500 ft per Oregon Discovery. Fruiting Jul-Dec per Wikipedia; more common in second-growth forests than old-growth. Soil temp range estimated from general chanterelle ecology (no precise PNW sensor study found). Precipitation range reflects need for sustained fall rains to trigger fruiting.

host_species.notes: Primary associate for yellow morels in riparian zones; river bottoms in eastern Cascades and along Columbia River are excellent hunting grounds.
Yellow morels strongly associate with cottonwood and ash in PNW.
Burn morels fruit prolifically in post-fire conifer stands, especially first spring after fire.

species.soil_type_notes: Sandy river bottoms and floodplains for yellow morels; post-fire conifer stands for burn morels. Soil temp ~50°F (10°C) is critical trigger for fruiting. Early season warmth is most crucial; moisture becomes increasingly important later.
fauna_partners: elk and deer soil disturbance in riparian zones
sources: Iowa State Extension: Soil Temperatures as Predictors for Mushroom Emergence (Mihail 2014) — https://naturalresources.extension.iastate.edu/post/soil-temperatures-predictors-mushroom-emergence
Salish Mushrooms: Finding Morels in Washington — https://salishmushrooms.com/finding-morels-in-washington-a-guide-to-habitat-timing-techniques-and-safety/
species.manual_notes: Scientific name updated to M. americana (yellow morels in PNW; M. importuna for landscape morels). Soil temp 50°F/10°C trigger per Iowa State Extension citing Mihail (2014). Season Mar-Jul per Salish Mushrooms, varying by elevation: Mar-Apr low, Apr-May mid, May-Jul high. Burn morels (various Morchella spp.) also relevant but use same environmental thresholds. Precipitation range estimated; rain events in May-Jun can trigger additional flushes.

host_species.notes: Common host through BC and to Alaska; troops often found under Sitka spruce.
Found near huckleberry in North America.
Non-selective mycorrhizal generalist; associates with birch in boreal/subarctic zones.

species.soil_type_notes: Strong affinity for acidic, sandy, nutrient-poor soils. Found amongst heather, bilberry, and deep carpets of moss and sphagnum. Avoids chalky soils.
sources: UBC Beaty Museum: Mushrooms Up! Cortinarius caperatus — https://explore.beatymuseum.ubc.ca/mushroomsup/C_caperatus.html
species.manual_notes: Season Sep-Nov in North America per Wikipedia. Non-selective mycorrhizal generalist per Fungi Atlas. Lowlands to tree line per Fungi Atlas. Soil temp and precip ranges estimated from general boreal/temperate fungal ecology; no PNW-specific sensor studies found. Elevation range set broadly (lowlands to tree line).

host_species.notes: Primary host in PNW per UBC Mushrooms Up (H. neorepandum in Sitka spruce and mixed conifer forests).
Found in mixed conifer forests alongside chanterelles.
Mixed conifer forests in Cascades and Coast Range.

species.soil_type_notes: Mossy, leafy ground in coniferous or mixed forests. Often found at same locations as chanterelles. Insect-resistant like chanterelles.
sources: UBC Beaty Museum: Mushrooms Up! Hydnum neorepandum — https://explore.beatymuseum.ubc.ca/mushroomsup/H_neorepandum.html
species.manual_notes: PNW species may actually be H. neorepandum (described 2018, previously lumped with H. repandum) per UBC. Season: late summer through late fall in Cascades/Coast Range; Jan-Apr on southern OR coast per Oregon Discovery. Phenology months include both windows. Soil temp and precip ranges estimated from chanterelle-adjacent habitat ecology. Note: H. washingtonianum and H. subolympicum also occur in PNW per Wikipedia.

host_species.notes: Saprophytic on dead/dying hardwood; grows near old wounds and on snags.
Various oak species are hosts in western North America.
Ash is a known North American host per Wikipedia.

species.soil_type_notes: Saprophytic/weakly parasitic; grows on dead or dying hardwood rather than from soil. Requires high humidity (85-90% relative humidity). Able to withstand cold temperatures and frost. Soil conditions less critical than substrate (host wood).
fauna_partners: woodpecker wound sites create entry points
species.manual_notes: Season Oct-Feb on west coast per Wikipedia. Hosts in North America include maple, ash, oaks per Wikipedia. Optimal mycelial growth at 25-26°C and pH 5.0-9.0 (optimal 6.0) per cultivation studies cited in Wikipedia. Soil temp range reflects ambient conditions during fruiting season rather than direct soil requirement (saprophyte on wood, not mycorrhizal). Precipitation range estimated to maintain high humidity requirement.
